Powdered Milk for Emergencies

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-18-2012 03:49 PM

Anyone have a favorite brand of nonfat dry milk they keep around for emergency use?  With the winter weather starting to get worse, I thought it would be a good idea to keep some in the house for times when the roads aren't safe.  Packets or canister, what is your preference?

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. D/day ~ RHR 55 ~ Between 5.9-6.9 A1cs, av. 6.5

‎01-18-2012 04:07 PM

powerwalker2 wrote:

Anyone have a favorite brand of nonfat dry milk they keep around for emergency use?  With the winter weather starting to get worse, I thought it would be a good idea to keep some in the house for times when the roads aren't safe.  Packets or canister, what is your preference?

I don't like or drink milk, but I do keep a small amount around for an occasional recipe.  I buy the "milk boxes" like the ones made for kid's school lunches.

 

I still remember how horrible powdered milk tasted when I was a kid, probably one reason why I hate milk now.

 

Lizzy

‎01-18-2012 05:20 PM

powerwalker2 wrote:

Anyone have a favorite brand of nonfat dry milk they keep around for emergency use?  With the winter weather starting to get worse, I thought it would be a good idea to keep some in the house for times when the roads aren't safe.  Packets or canister, what is your preference?

 

I keep both skim and whole powdered milk, but only use it to make yoghurt. I could go months without needing milk if not for that. In an emergency I can use water for my bedtime muesli.

 

I just buy cheap "home" supermarket brands. Our dairy industry has strict quality controls, so the quality is good regardless of price or brand.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎01-18-2012 07:26 PM

I don't drink milk, because I'd rather use those carbs somewhere else. I prefer unsweetened almond milk instead. About 3 gms carbs in 8 oz. It comes in plain, chocolate and vanilla, in shelf-stable aseptic cartons, no refrigeration needed. The cartons I have in my cabinet are dated July 2012, so they could last me all winter if needed.The  vanilla is good every day in my coffee, oatmeal, and occasionally when I eat cold cereal. The chocolate is great warmed in the microwave as a hot cocoa substitute before bed. I use stevia to sweeten.

*********************************
You're among friends here!
*********************************
SugarFrosted aka AnnaM, retired ER/Oncology-Chemotherapy nurse
Little Rock, Arkansas
Diagnosed Type 2, Jun'09 at age 57
Jun'09 A1c: 7.2 F 154 wt 265 lbs
Dec'09 A1c: 5.5 F 80
Jun'10 A1c: 5.4 F 82

Jun'11 A1c: 5.3 F 76

Sep'15 A1c: 5.5 F 81
Reduced-Carb Mealplan & 1 hr Daily Exercise! NO Meds!
105 lb total weightloss
Self-employed baker/cake designer since 1988...life doesn't get much harder for a diabetic, imo. My Online Cake Gallery: http://www.sugarfrosted.com/

I'm with Lizzy, the boxed milk is the way to go. It has quite a long shelf life and tastes like real milk, because it is.

‎01-19-2012 12:23 AM - edited ‎01-19-2012 12:40 AM

Thanks, everyone, and in what part of the grocery would I find cartons of shelf-stable boxed milk?  Do they come in a fat free skim milk version?  (Asking mostly for hubby, who isn't a fan of the powdered, either.  As for me, I use only a dribble of milk occasionally in oatmeal, since I prefer to stick with unsweetened soy milk (4g carbs/cup) or unsweetened almond milk (2g carbs per cup) on my cereal mix most of the time.)

Nancy ~ T2 since '98 ~ 17 yrs ~ D&E 11yrs ~ treadmill, elliptical, bike 15-20 minutes 2-3x/day (includes evenings), dumbbells/strength-training, small portions heart-healthy high-fiber/low-fat fuel/carb-counting, modified Mediterranean/semi-vegetarian plant-based diet; 500mg Glucophage XR x4, 5mg Glipizide ER x4, 4000IU Vit. ‎01-19-2012 07:55 AM

They are typically in one of those center aisles most of us avoid. Depends a bit on the grocery store, but I've often seen them towards one end or the other of the baking supplies.

Re: Powdered Milk for Emergencies

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post

  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎01-19-2012 12:39 PM

I keep powdered milk around.  I only use it for our cooking though instead of real milk.   I have a bad lactose intolerance so I have to be careful of using 'liquid milk'.  One reason we've switched to drinking the soy milks.  But the powdered milk makes cooked items just as well if not better then real milk.  I can use it in pancake mix, and the 2nd or 3rd day, the mix doesn't turn icky looking like when liquid milk is used.   And the cooked or baked items turn out just as delicious.  Best thing is, I get one of the Giant sized boxed of the powdered milk and after opening it, keep it in the refrigerator.  It keeps forever in there!  I don't have to worry about throwing it out or wasting it or bugs getting in to it.  I buy maybe 3 boxes of it a year. 

 

For real milk, I was getting it mainly for my daughter to drink, 2% type.  I was told it freezes nicely, so, even now, we have 2 gallons in the 1/2 gal size frozen in our deep freezer.  It will keep for around 8-9 months good, and when we thaw it out in the frig, the little bit of cream will separate, but a good shaking to mix works.  This makes it nice for when milk is on sale I can keep it stocked and not be paying the high prices.  


Mother of Courtney, Dx'd Type 1 in 2006 at age 14.

Self: Dx'd "Pre"-Diabetic 8/8/14 *and we all know what that means*

Funny about those center aisles.  You never know what you're going to find there.  Yesterday I was in a hurry to go check out after all my shopping was done, and made a bee-line down the nearest aisle, to find myself surrounded by a sea of pink and red Valentine's stuff of all kinds!  Which made me buzz down the aisle even faster.  LOL

Dragonstar wrote:

I keep powdered milk around.  I only use it for our cooking though instead of real milk.   I have a bad lactose intolerance so I have to be careful of using 'liquid milk'.  One reason we've switched to drinking the soy milks.  But the powdered milk makes cooked items just as well if not better then real milk.  I can use it in pancake mix, and the 2nd or 3rd day, the mix doesn't turn icky looking like when liquid milk is used.   And the cooked or baked items turn out just as delicious.  Best thing is, I get one of the Giant sized boxed of the powdered milk and after opening it, keep it in the refrigerator.  It keeps forever in there!  I don't have to worry about throwing it out or wasting it or bugs getting in to it.  I buy maybe 3 boxes of it a year. 

 

For real milk, I was getting it mainly for my daughter to drink, 2% type.  I was told it freezes nicely, so, even now, we have 2 gallons in the 1/2 gal size frozen in our deep freezer.  It will keep for around 8-9 months good, and when we thaw it out in the frig, the little bit of cream will separate, but a good shaking to mix works.  This makes it nice for when milk is on sale I can keep it stocked and not be paying the high prices.  

Thank you, Dragonstar!  I never would have thought of refrigerating the powdered milk or freezing the liquid milk.  Great ideas!!
